original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa🔽Suttantapiṭaka🔽Majjhimanikāya
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa  suttantapiṭaka  majjhima nikāya
translated: Homage to the Blessed One, the Worthy One, the Rightly Self-awakened One🔽The Collection of Long Discourses

original: Mūlapaṇṇāsapāḷi
analyzed: mūla paṇṇāsa pāḷi
translated: The Middle Length Collection🔽The First Fifty Discourses

original: Saṃgāyanassa pucchā vissajjanā
analyzed: saṃgāyanassa pucchā vissajjanā
translated: The Questions and Answers of the Recitation

original: Pucchā – paṭhamamahāsaṃgītikāle āvuso dhammasaṃgāhakā mahākassapādayo mahātheravarā dīghanikāyaṃ saṃgāyitvā tadanantaraṃ kiṃ nāma pāvacanaṃ saṃgāyiṃsu.
analyzed: pucchā paṭhama mahā saṃgīti kāle āvuso dhamma saṃgāhakāḥ mahākassapa ādayaḥ mahā thera varāḥ dīgha nikāyam saṃgāyitvā tad anantaram kim nāma saṃgāyiṃsu
translated: Questions – After the elders, the great Kassapa and so on, the compilers of the Dhamma, had compiled the Long Collection during the first great recitation, what other teaching did they compile?

original: Vissajjanā – paṭhamamahāsaṃgītikāle bhante dhammasaṃgāhakā mahākassapādayo mahātheravarā dīghanikāyaṃ saṃgāyitvā tadanantaraṃ majjhimaṃ nāma nikāyaṃ saṃgāyiṃsu.
analyzed: vissajjanā paṭhama mahā saṃgīti kāle bhante dhamma saṃgāhakāḥ mahākassapa ādayaḥ mahā thera varāḥ dīgha nikāyam saṃgāyitvā tad anantaram majjhimam nāma nikāyam saṃgāyiṃsu
translated: Answers – Venerable sirs, after the elders, the great Kassapa and so on, the compilers of the Dhamma, had compiled the Long Collection during the first great recitation, they then compiled the collection called the Middle Length.

original: Pucchā – majjhimanikāyo nāma āvuso mūlapaṇṇāsako majjhima paṇṇāsako uparipaṇṇāsakoti paṇṇāsakavasena tividho, tattha kataraṃ paṇṇāsakaṃ paṭhamaṃ saṃgāyiṃsu.
analyzed: pucchā majjhimanikāyaḥ nāma āvuso mūla paṇṇāsakaḥ majjhima paṇṇāsako upari paṇṇāsakaḥ ti paṇṇāsaka vasena tividhaḥ tattha kataram paṇṇāsakam paṭhamam saṃgāyiṃsu
translated: Questions – The Middle Length Collection, sirs, is threefold by way of the fifty, namely the First Fifty, the Middle Fifty, and the Upper Fifty. Which fifty did they compile first?

original: Vissajjanā – tīsu bhante paṇṇāsakesu mūlapaṇṇāsakaṃ nāma pāvacanaṃ dhammasaṃgāhakā mahātheravarā paṭhamaṃ saṃgāyiṃsu.🔽Pucchā – mūlapaṇṇāsakepi āvuso pañcavaggā paṇṇāsa ca suttāni, tesu kataraṃ vaggaṃ katarañca suttaṃ paṭhamaṃ saṃgāyiṃsu.
analyzed: vissajjanā tīsu bhante paṇṇāsakesu mūlapaṇṇāsakam nāma pāvacanam dhamma saṃgāhakāḥ mahā thera varā paṭhamam saṃgāyiṃsu  pucchā mūla paṇṇāsake pi āvuso pañca vaggā paṇṇāsa ca suttāni tesu kataram vaggam kataram ca suttam paṭhamam saṃgāyiṃsu
translated: “The ‘root-fifty’ is the first of the three ‘fifty-sections’ to be compiled by the great elder-nobles, the compilers of the Dhamma.”🔽“In the ‘root-fifty’ there are five ‘groups’ and fifty suttas. Which ‘group’ and which sutta did they compile first?”

original: Vissajjanā – mūlapaṇṇāsake bhante pañcasu vaggesu paṭhamaṃ mūlapariyāyavaggaṃ paṇṇāsakesu ca suttesu paṭhamaṃ mūlapariyāyasuttaṃ saṃgāyiṃsu.
analyzed: vissajjanā mūla paṇṇāsake bhante pañcasu vaggesu paṭhamam mūlapariyāya vaggam paṇṇāsakesu ca suttesu paṭhamam mūlapariyāya suttam saṃgāyiṃsu
translated: “In the ‘root-fifty’ there are five ‘groups.’ They compiled the ‘Root-Enumeration Group’ first. And in the fifty suttas they compiled the ‘Root-Enumeration Sutta’ first.”

original: Sādhu āvuso mayampi dāni tatoyeva paṭṭhāya saṃgītipubbaṅgamāni pucchāvissajjanakiccāni kātuṃ samārabhāma.
analyzed: sādhu āvuso mayam pi dāni tatas yeva paṭṭhāya saṃgīti pubbaṅgamāni pucchā vissajjana kiccāni kātum samārabhāma
translated: “Good, friend. Now let us begin the work of questioning and answering in order to establish the sequence of the compilation.”

original: Mūlapariyāyasutta
analyzed: mūla pariyāya sutta
translated: The Root-Enumeration Sutta

original: Pucchā – tena āvuso bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena mūlapariyāyasuttaṃ kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā tena āvuso bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena mūlapariyāya suttam kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitaṃ
translated: “Friend, by whom was the Root-Enumeration Sutta spoken? For whose benefit was it spoken? On what subject does it touch?

original: Vissajjanā – ukkaṭṭhāyaṃ bhante pañcasate brāhmaṇakulā pabbajite ārabbha bhāsitaṃ,
analyzed: vissajjanā ukkaṭṭhā ayam bhante pañca sate brāhmaṇa kulā pabbajite ārabbha bhāsitam
translated: The answer is: in the Ukkatthā Sutta, it was said with reference to the five hundred brahmin families who had gone forth.

original: pañcasatā bhante brāhmaṇakulā pabbajitā bhikkhū pariyattiṃ nissāya mānaṃ uppādesuṃ,
analyzed: pañca satā bhante brāhmaṇa kulā pabbajitāḥ bhikkhū pariyattim nissāya mānam uppādesuṃ
translated: The five hundred brahmin families who had gone forth as monks, relying on the scriptures, gave rise to conceit.

original: tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: tasmin bhante vatthusmin bhāsitam
translated: It was said with reference to that matter, venerable sir.

original: Pucchā – taṃ panāvuso suttaṃ bhagavatā katihi vārehi katihi ca antogadhapadehi vibhajitvā bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā tam pana āvuso suttam bhagavatā katihi vārehi katihi ca antogadha padehi vibhajitvā bhāsitam
translated: Question: But, friend, in how many sections and with how many terms was that sutta spoken by the Blessed One?

original: Vissajjanā – taṃ pana bhante mūlapariyāyasuttaṃ bhagavatā aṭṭhahi ca vārehi catuvīsatiyā ca antogadhapadehi vibhajitvā desitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā tat pana bhante mūla pariyāya suttam bhagavatā aṭṭhahi ca vārehi catuvīsatiyā ca antogadha padehi vibhajitvā desitam
translated: Answer: But, venerable sir, that Mūlapariyāya Sutta was taught by the Blessed One in eight sections and with twenty-four terms.

original: Sabbāsavasutta
analyzed: sabbāsavasutta
translated: The All-corruptions Sutta

original: Pucchā – dutiyaṃ panāvuso sabbāsavasuttaṃ bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā dutiyam pana āvuso sabbāsava suttam bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha bhāsitam
translated: Question: But, friend, with reference to whom did the Blessed One speak the second All-corruptions Sutta?

original: Vissajjanā – sabbāsavasuttaṃ pana bhante bhagavatā sāvatthiyaṃ sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā sabbāsava suttam pana bhante bhagavatā sāvatthiyam sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha bhāsitaṃ
translated: Answer: But, venerable sir, the All-corruptions Sutta was spoken by the Blessed One with reference to several monks at Sāvatthī.

original: Pucchā – tatthāvuso bhagavatā āsavā katihi pakārehi vibhajitvā dassitā.
analyzed: pucchā tattha āvuso bhagavatā āsavā katihi pakārehi vibhajitvā dassitā
translated: Question: But, friend, in how many ways did the Blessed One show the corruptions?

original: Vissajjanā – sattahi bhante pakārehi vibhajitvā āsavā bhagavatā pakāsitā.
analyzed: vissajjanā sattahi bhante pakārehi vibhajitvā āsavā bhagavatā pakāsitā
translated: The answer is: The cankers were revealed by the Blessed One in seven ways.

original: Dhammadāyādasutta
analyzed: dhammadāyāda sutta
translated: The Inheritance in Dhamma Sutta

original: Pucchā – dhammadāyādasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā dhammadāyāda suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: Question: But, friend, on the occasion when the Blessed One spoke the Inheritance in Dhamma Sutta, who was it that he spoke it to, and on what subject?

original: Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha bhāsitaṃ, bhagavato ca bhante bhikkhusaṅghassa ca tadā mahālābhasakkāro udapādi, tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha bhāsitam bhagavataḥ ca bhante bhikkhu saṅghassa ca tadā mahā lābha sakkāraḥ udapādi tasmim bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: Answer: At Savatthi, friend, the Blessed One spoke it to a number of bhikkhus, and it was on the occasion of the great gain and honour that had arisen for the Blessed One and the bhikkhu Saṅgha.

original: Pucchā – tatthāvuso dve anusandhayo, tesu paṭhame anusandhimhi kathaṃ bhagavatā bhikkhūnaṃ ovādo dinno.
analyzed: pucchā tattha āvuso dve anusandhayo tesu paṭhame anusandhimhi katham bhagavatā bhikkhūnam ovādaḥ dinno
translated: Question: But, friend, there are two considerations there. How was the Blessed One’s advice given to the bhikkhus in the first consideration?

original: Vissajjanā – paṭhame bhante anusandhimhi dhammadāyādā me bhikkhave bhavatha mā āmisadāyādā,
analyzed: vissajjanā paṭhame bhante anusandhimhi dhamma dāyādāḥ me bhikkhave bhavatha mā āmisa dāyādāḥ
translated: Answer: In the first consideration, friend, the Blessed One’s advice was given thus: ‘Be inheritors of my Dhamma, bhikkhus, and not inheritors of material things.

original: atthi me tumhesu anukampā, kinti me sāvakā dhammadāyādā bhaveyyuṃ no āmisadāyādāti
analyzed: atthi me tumhesu anukampā kinti me sāvakā dhamma dāyādāḥ bhaveyyum no āmisa dāyādā ti
translated: I have compassion for you, thinking: “How can my disciples become inheritors of my Dhamma and not inheritors of material things?” ’

original: evamādinā bhagavatā bhikkhūnaṃ ovādo dinno.
analyzed: evamādinā bhagavatā bhikkhūnam ovādaḥ dinno
translated: So the Blessed One’s advice was given to the bhikkhus in the first consideration thus.

original: Dhammadāyādā me bhikkhave bhavatha mā āmisadāyādā, atthi me tumhesu anukampā kinti me sāvakā dhammadāyādā bhaveyyuṃ, no āmisadāyādā.
analyzed: dhamma dāyādāḥ me bhikkhave bhavatha mā āmisa dāyādāḥ atthi me tumhesu anukampā kinti me sāvakāḥ dhamma dāyādāḥ bhaveyyuṃ no āmisa dāyādāḥ
translated: “Be heirs in Dhamma, O bhikkhus, not heirs in material things. I have compassion for you, thinking: ‘How can my disciples become heirs in Dhamma, not heirs in material things?’”

original: Pucchā – dutiye panāvuso anusandhimhi āyasmatā sāriputtattherena dhammasenāpatinā kīdisī dhammadesanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: pucchā dutiye pana āvuso anusandhimhi āyasmatā sāriputta therena dhamma senāpatinā kīdisī dhamma desanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: Question: But, friend, in the second connection, how did the Elder Sāriputta, the General of the Dhamma, expound the teaching by analysis?

original: Vissajjanā – dutiye pana bhante anusandhimhi āyasmatā sāriputtattherena dhammasenāpatinā
analyzed: vissajjanā dutiye pana bhante anusandhimhi āyasmatā sāriputta therena dhamma senāpatinā
translated: Reply: In the second connection, venerable sir, the Elder Sāriputta, the General of the Dhamma,

original: satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakānaṃ vivekaṃ ananusikkhataṃ tīhi ṭhānehi gārayutaṃ,🔽anusikkhantānañca tīhi ṭhānehi pāsaṃsataṃ, soḷasa ca pāpake dhamme tesañca pahānāya
analyzed: satthu pavivittassa viharataḥ sāvakānam vivekam an anusikkhatam tīhi ṭhānehi gārayutam  anusikkhantānam ca tīhi ṭhānehi soḷasa ca pāpake dhamme tesañca pahānāya
translated: when the Teacher was living secluded, expounded the teaching by analysis to the disciples who were not training in seclusion, censuring them in three respects,

original: majjhimā paṭipadā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: majjhimā paṭipadā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: and to those who were training in seclusion, commending them in three respects, and he expounded the sixteen evil states and the middle way for the abandoning of those states.

original: Bhayabheravasutta
analyzed: bhayabheravasutta
translated: The Discourse on Fear and Dread

original: Pucchā – bhayabheravasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā bhayabherava suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: Question: But, friend, in regard to the Discourse on Fear and Dread, where was it spoken, by whom was it spoken, and on whose account?

original: Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante jāṇussoṇiṃ brāhmaṇaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ, jāṇussoṇi
analyzed: vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante jāṇussoṇim brāhmaṇam ārabbha bhāsitam jāṇussoṇi
translated: The Releasing: at Sāvatthi, it seems, concerning the brahmin Jānussoṇi.🔽The brahmin Jāṇussoṇi, it seems, went to the Blessed One and said: “Master Gotama, those young men of good family who have gone forth from the home life into homelessness under Master Gotama, do Master Gotama make them do work?🔽Do they do work? Do they make Master Gotama do work?

original: bhante brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca “ye me bho gotama kulaputtā bhavantaṃ🔽gotamaṃ uddissa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitā, bhavaṃ tesaṃ gotamo pubbaṅgamo, bhavaṃ🔽Tesaṃ gotamo bahukāro, bhavaṃ tesaṃ gotamo samādapetā, bhoto ca pana gotamassa sā janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjatī”ti, tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.🔽Anaṅgaṇasutta🔽Pucchā – anaṅgaṇasuttaṃ panāvuso kattha kaṃ ārabbha kena bhāsitaṃ.🔽Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha āyasmatā sāriputtattherena dhammasenāpatinā bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: bhante brāhmaṇaḥ bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā etat avoca ye me bho gotama kula puttāḥ bhavantam  gotamam uddissa saddhāḥ agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajitāḥ bhavan tesam gotamo pubbaṅgamaḥ bhavan  tesam gotamaḥ bahu kāraḥ bhavam tesam gotamaḥ samādapetā bhoto ca pana gotamassa sā janatā diṭṭha anugatim āpajjati iti tasmim bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam  anaṅgaṇa sutta  pucchā anaṅgaṇa suttam pana āvuso kattha kam ārabbha kena bhāsitam  vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha āyasmatā sāriputta therena dhamma senāpatinā bhāsitam
translated: Does Master Gotama do work?” The Blessed One said: “Brahmin, those young men of good family who have gone forth from the home life into homelessness under me do not do work.🔽I do not make them do work.

original: Ākaṅkheyyasutta🔽Pucchā – ākaṅkheyyasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: ākaṅkheyyasutta 🔽pucchā ākaṅkheyya suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha bhāsitam

original: Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha bhāsitam
translated: The Source: At Savatthi, the Lord Buddha spoke this discourse in reference to a number of monks.

original: Vatthasutta
analyzed: vattha sutta
translated: The Case

original: Pucchā – vatthasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā vattha suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha bhāsitam
translated: Question: “Friend, where was the Case Discourse spoken by the Blessed One?

original: Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha bhāsitam
translated: Answer: At Savatthi, the Lord Buddha spoke this discourse in reference to a number of monks.

original: Sallekhasutta
analyzed: sallekha sutta
translated: The Investigation

original: Pucchā – sallekhasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā sallekha suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: Question: “Friend, where was the Investigation Discourse spoken by the Blessed One? In reference to whom? On what subject?

original: Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante āyasmantaṃ mahācundaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ, āyasmā mahācundo🔽bhante bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca “yā imā bhante anekavihitā diṭṭhiyo loke
analyzed: vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante āyasmantam mahācundam ārabbha bhāsitam āyasmā mahācundaḥ  bhante bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā etat avoca yāḥ imāḥ bhante aneka vihitāḥ diṭṭhiyaḥ loke
translated: Answer: At Savatthi, the Lord Buddha spoke this discourse in reference to the venerable Maha Cunda. The venerable Maha Cunda

original: uppajjanti, attavādapaṭisaṃyuttā vā lokavādapaṭisaṃyuttā vā, ādimeva nu kho bhante
analyzed: uppajjanti atta vāda paṭisaṃyuttāḥ vā loka vāda paṭisaṃyuttāḥ vā ādim eva nu kho bhante
translated: approached the Lord Buddha and said: “Lord, there are many and various speculative views that arise in the world, such as: ‘The world and the self are identical,’ or ‘The world and the self are different.’

original: bhikkhuno manasikaroto evametāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ pahānaṃ hoti, evametāsaṃ diṭṭhīnaṃ paṭinissaggo
analyzed: bhikkhunaḥ manasikarotaḥ evam etāsam diṭṭhīnam pahānam hoti evam etāsam diṭṭhīnam paṭinissaggo
translated: But, Lord, how does a monk who investigates come to the abandonment and relinquishment of these views?

original: hotī”ti, tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: hoti iti tasmim bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: was spoken, venerable Sir, with reference to that matter.

original: Pucchā – tattha ca āvuso kati pariyāyā kati ca antogadhapadāni bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitāni.
analyzed: pucchā tattha ca āvuso kati pariyāyā kati ca antogadha padāni bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitāni
translated: Question: And how many modes and how many component parts were analysed and explained by the Fortunate One there, friend?

original: Vissajjanā – tattha bhante pañca pariyāyā catucattālīsa ca antogadhapadāni bhagavatā vitthārena bhāsitāni.
analyzed: vissajjanā tattha bhante pañca pariyāyā catucattālīsa ca antogadha padāni bhagavatā vitthārena bhāsitāni
translated: Answer: There, venerable Sir, five modes and forty-four component parts were spoken by the Fortunate One in detail.

original: Sammāṭṭhisutta
analyzed: sammāṭṭhi sutta
translated: The Discourse about Right View

original: Pucchā – sammādiṭṭhisuttaṃ panāvuso kattha kaṃ ārabbha kena bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā sammādiṭṭhi suttam pana āvuso kattha kam ārabbha kena bhāsitam
translated: Question: But with reference to whom, friend, was the Discourse about Right View spoken? By whom was it spoken?

original: Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha āyasmatā sāriputtattherena dhammasenāpatinā bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha āyasmatā sāriputta therena dhamma senāpatinā bhāsitam
translated: Answer: With reference to many monks, venerable Sir, at Sāvatthī, it was spoken by the Elder Sāriputta, the General of the Dhamma.

original: Pucchā – kassa āvuso vacanaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā kassa āvuso vacanam
translated: Question: Whose utterance is it, friend?

original: Vissajjanā – bhagavato bhante vacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
analyzed: vissajjanā bhagavataḥ bhante vacanam arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Answer: It is the Fortunate One’s utterance, venerable Sir, the Worthy One, the Perfect Sambuddha’s.

original: Pucchā – kenāvuso ābhataṃ.
analyzed: pucchā kena āvuso ābhatam
translated: Question: By whom was it brought, friend?

original: Vissajjanā – paramparāya bhante ābhataṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā paramparāya bhante ābhatam
translated: Answer: It was brought, venerable Sir, by a succession (of teachers).

original: Mahāsatipaṭṭhānasutta
analyzed: mahāsatipaṭṭhāna sutta
translated: The Great Discourse on the Foundations of Mindfulness

original: Pucchā – mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttaṃ panāvuso yogāvacarānaṃ bahupakārattā dīghanikāye
analyzed: pucchā mahāsati paṭṭhāna suttam pana āvuso yoga avacarānam bahu pakāra ttā dīgha nikāye
translated: Question: But, friend, the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta is of great help to meditators, and it is included in the Dīgha Nikāya.

original: ca idha cāti dvīsu nikāyesu porāṇakehi saṃgītikārehi dvikkhattuṃ saṃgāyitvā vitthārena🔽patiṭṭhāpitaṃ, taṃ amhehi dīghanikāye yathānuppattavasena pucchitañca vissajjitañca.
analyzed: ca idha ca ati dvīsu nikāyesu porāṇakehi saṃgīti kārehi dvi khattum saṃgāyitvā vitthārena  patiṭṭhāpitam tam amhehi dīgha nikāye yathā anuppatta vasena pucchitam ca vissajjitam ca
translated: Question: But, friend, the Great Discourse on the Foundations of Mindfulness was recited twice by the ancient Reciters in the two Collections, namely, in the Long Collection and here in the Middle Length🔽Collection, because it is so helpful to meditators. It was asked and answered by us in the Long Collection in the way it occurs there.

original: Tathāpi yogāvacarānaṃ bahupakārattāyeva taṃ idānipi yathānuppattavasena puna pucchissāmi,
analyzed: tathā api bahu pakāra ttāya iva tam yathā anuppatta vasena puna pucchissāmi
translated: Still, because it is so helpful to meditators, I shall ask it and answer it again in the way it occurs here.

original: taṃ panetaṃ āvuso mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttaṃ bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: tam pana itam āvuso mahāsatipaṭṭhāna suttam bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha bhāsitam
translated: But, friend, by whom was this Great Discourse on the Foundations of Mindfulness spoken?

original: Vissajjanā – kurūsu bhante kammāsadhamme nāma kurūnaṃ nigame sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā kurūsu bhante kammāsadhamme nāma kurūnam nigame sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha bhāsitam
translated: Answer: It was spoken, venerable sir, by the Blessed One in the Kuru country at Kammāsadhamma, a town of the Kurus, with reference to a number of bhikkhus.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha ānāpānassati kāyānupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso tattha āna apāna sati kāya anupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: Question: But, friend, how was mindfulness of breathing as a meditation subject expounded by the Blessed One in the detailed explanation?

original: Vissajjanā – idha bhikkhave bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato
analyzed: vissajjanā idha bhikkhave bhikkhu arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ
translated: Answer: Here, friend, a bhikkhu, gone to the forest or to the root of a tree or to an empty place,

original: vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā
analyzed: vā nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: or sits down cross-legged, sets his body upright, and establishes mindfulness in front of him,

original: so satova assasati, satova passasati, dīghaṃ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: saḥ satas iva assasati satas iva passasati dīgham vai assasantaḥ dīgham assasāmi iti pajānāti
translated: and he, being mindful, breathes in, and he is mindful, breathing out, if he breathes in long, he knows ‘I breathe in long’,

original: dīghaṃ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti, evamādinā bhante tattha ānāpānassati
analyzed: dīgham vā passasantaḥ dīgham passasāmi iti pajānāti evamādinā bhante tattha
translated: if he breathes out long, he knows ‘I breathe out long’, and so on, in this way, reverend Sir, mindfulness while breathing

original: kāyānupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: kāya anupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: is explained by the Fortunate One after dividing it into the contemplation of the body.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha iriyāpathakāyānupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso tattha iriyāpatha kāya anupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: Question: And how, reverend Sir, is the contemplation of the body by way of the postures explained by the Fortunate One after dividing it?

original: Vissajjanā – puna caparaṃ bhikkhave bhikkhu gacchanto vā gacchāmīti pajānāti, ṭhito
analyzed: vissajjanā puna caparam bhikkhave bhikkhu gacchantaḥ vā gacchāmi iti pajānāti ṭhitaḥ
translated: Answer: Furthermore, monks, a monk, when going, knows ‘I am going’, when standing,

original: vā ṭhitomhīti pajānāti, nisinno vā nisinnomhīti pajānāti, sayāno vā sayānomhīti pajānāti,
analyzed: vā ṭhitaḥ umhi iti pajānāti nisinnaḥ vā nisinnaḥ umhi iti pajānāti sa yānaḥ vā sa yānaḥ umhi iti pajānāti
translated: he knows ‘I am standing’, when sitting, he knows ‘I am sitting’, when lying down, he knows ‘I am lying down’,

original: evamādinā bhante bhagavatā iriyāpathakāyānupassanā bhāvanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: evamādinā bhante bhagavatā iriyāpatha kāya anupassanā bhāvanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: and so on, in this way, reverend Sir, the development of the contemplation of the body by way of the postures is explained by the Fortunate One after dividing it.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha sampajaññakāyānupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso tattha sampajañña kāya anupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: Question – But, friend, how was the contemplation of the body as subject to destruction, in this context, revealed and explained by the Blessed One in detail?

original: Vissajjanā – puna caparaṃ bhikkhave bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti,
analyzed: vissajjanā puna caparam bhikkhave bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajāna kārī hoti
translated: Answer – Furthermore, monks, a monk is one who practises with full awareness when going forward and returning;

original: ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe🔽sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme
analyzed: ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇe  sampajāna kārī hoti asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajāna kārī hoti uccāra passāva kamme
translated: he is one who practises with full awareness when looking ahead and looking aside; he is one who practises with full awareness when drawing in and extending the limbs; he is one who practises with full awareness when wearing the robes and carrying the alms bowl;🔽he is one who practises with full awareness when eating, drinking, consuming food, and tasting; he is one who practises with full awareness when defecating and urinating;

original: sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī🔽hoti, evamādinā bhante bhagavatā tattha sampajaññakāyānupassanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajāna kārī  evamādinā bhante bhagavatā tattha sampajañña kāya anupassanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: he is one who practises with full awareness when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, talking, and keeping silent.🔽Thus, venerable sir, the contemplation of the body as subject to destruction, in this context, was revealed and explained by the Blessed One in detail.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha paṭikūlamanasikārakāyānupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso tattha paṭikūla manasikāra kāya anupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: Question – But, friend, how was the contemplation of the body as repulsive, in this context, revealed and explained by the Blessed One in detail?

original: Vissajjanā – puna caparaṃ bhikkhave bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ uddhaṃ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā
analyzed: vissajjanā puna ca param bhikkhave bhikkhu imam eva kāyam uddham pāda talāḥ adhas kesa matthakā
translated: Abandoning: furthermore, monks, a monk, in this body, from the soles of the feet on up, from the crown of the head on down,

original: tacapariyantaṃ pūraṃ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesālomā
analyzed: taca pariyantam pūram nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati atthi imasmin kāye kesālomā
translated: surrounded by skin, filled with various kinds of unclean things, reflects: there are in this body head hairs, body hairs,

original: nakhā dantā taco evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā paṭikūlamanasikārakāyānupassanā
analyzed: nakhā dantā tacaḥ evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā paṭikūla manasikāra kāya anupassanā
translated: nails, teeth, skin, and so on, reverend Sir, here the Realised One, after dividing the contemplation of the body as a repulsive thing,

original: vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: has explained it.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha dhātumanasikārakāyānupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso tattha dhātu manasikāra kāya anupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: Question: But, reverend Sir, how has the contemplation of the body as an element, after dividing it, been explained by the Fortunate One?

original: Vissajjanā – puna caparaṃ bhikkhave bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ yathāṭhitaṃ yathāpaṇihitaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā puna ca param bhikkhave bhikkhu imam eva kāyam yathā ṭhitam yathā paṇihitam
translated: Abandoning: furthermore, monks, a monk, in this body, as it is placed, as it is disposed,

original: dhātuso paccavekkhati atthi imasmiṃ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātu
analyzed: dhātuso paccavekkhati atthi imasmin kāye pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu
translated: reflects on its elements: there is in this body the earth element, the water element, the fire element, the air element,

original: evamādinā bhante bhagavatā dhātumanasikārakāyānupassanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: evamādinā bhante bhagavatā dhātu manasikāra kāya anupassanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: and so on, reverend Sir, here the Realised One, after dividing the contemplation of the body as an element, has explained it.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha nava sivathikakāyānupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso tattha nava sivathika kāya anupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: Question – But, friend, how has the meditation on the nine charnel-ground contemplations been expounded by the Blessed One in various ways?

original: Vissajjanā – puna caparaṃ bhikkhave bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṃ sivathikāya
analyzed: vissajjanā puna caparam bhikkhave bhikkhu seyyathā api passeyya sarīram sivathikāya
translated: Answer – Again, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu might see a body cast aside in a charnel ground,

original: chaḍḍitaṃ ekāhamataṃ vā dvīhamataṃ vā tīhamataṃ vā uddhumātakaṃ vinīlakaṃ vipubbakajātaṃ
analyzed: chaḍḍitam eka aha matam vā dvīha matam vā tīha matam vā uddhumātakam vinīlakam vipubbaka jātam
translated: dead for one day or for two days, or for three days, bloated, discoloured, festering.

original: so imameva kāyaṃ upasaṃharati “ayampi kho kāyo evaṃdhammo evaṃbhāvī evaṃanatīto”ti
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyam upasaṃharati ayam pi kho kāyaḥ evaṃdhammaḥ evaṃbhāvī evam anatītaḥ iti
translated: He then compares this same body with it thus: “This body, too, is of the same nature, will become like that, and will not escape from it.”

original: evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā nava sivathikakāyānupassanā bhāvanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā nava sivathika kāya anupassanāḥ bhāvanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: Thus, venerable sir, the meditation on the nine charnel-ground contemplations has been expounded by the Blessed One in various ways.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha vedanānupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitā.🔽Vissajjanā – idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sukhaṃ vā vedanaṃ vedayamāno “sukhaṃ vedanaṃ
analyzed: pucchā kathañca āvuso tattha vedanā anupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitā  vissajjanā idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sukham vā vedanam vedayamānaḥ sukham vedanam
translated: Question – But, friend, how has the contemplation of feelings been expounded by the Blessed One in various ways?🔽Answer – Here, bhikkhus, when experiencing a pleasant feeling a bhikkhu understands: “I experience a pleasant feeling”;

original: vedayāmī”ti pajānāti, dukkhaṃ vā vedanaṃ vedayamāno “dukkha vedanaṃ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti,
analyzed: vedayāmi iti pajānāti dukkham vā vedanam vedayamānaḥ dukkha vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti
translated: when experiencing a painful feeling he understands: “I experience a painful feeling”;

original: adukkhamasukhaṃ vā vedanaṃ vedayamāno “adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti,
analyzed: adukkham asukham vā vedanam vedayamānaḥ adukkham asukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti
translated: or when he is experiencing neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling he knows “I am experiencing neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.”

original: evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā vedanānupassanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā vedanā anupassanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: In this way, venerable Sir, the contemplation of feelings has been analysed and explained by the Fortunate One.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha cittānupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitā.
analyzed: pucchā kathañca āvuso tattha citta anupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitā
translated: Question: But how, reverend Sir, has the contemplation of mind been analysed and taught by the Fortunate One?

original: Vissajjanā – idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ “sarāgaṃ citta”nti pajānāti,🔽vītarāgaṃ vā cittaṃ “vītarāgaṃ citta”nti pajānāti, sadosaṃ vā vītadosaṃ vā samohaṃ🔽vā vītamohaṃ vā saṃkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ “saṃkhittaṃ citta”nti pajānāti, vikkhittaṃ vā
analyzed: vissajjanā idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sa rāgam vā cittam sa rāgam cittam iti pajānāti  vīta rāgam vā cittam vīta rāgam cittam iti pajānāti sa dosam vā vīta dosam vā sa moham  vā vīta moham vā saṃkhittam vā cittam saṃkhittam cittam iti pajānāti vikkhittam vā
translated: Answer: Here, reverend Sir, a monk when the mind has passion knows “the mind has passion,”🔽when the mind is without passion he knows “the mind is without passion,” when the mind has hate he knows “the mind has hate,” when the mind is without hate he knows “the mind is without hate,” when the mind has delusion he knows “the mind has delusion,” when the mind is without delusion he knows “the mind is without delusion,” when the mind is collected he knows “the mind is collected,” when the mind is scattered he knows “the mind is scattered,”

original: cittaṃ “vikkhittaṃ citta”nti pajānāti, evamādinā tattha bhagavatā cittānupassanā
analyzed: cittam vikkhittam cittam ti pajānāti evamādinā tattha bhagavatā citta anupassanā
translated: in this way, reverend Sir, the contemplation of mind

original: vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: has been analysed and explained by the Fortunate One.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha dhammānupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitā, taṃ saṅkhepamatteneva vissajjehi.
analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso tattha dhamma anupassanā bhagavatā vibhajitvā desitā tam saṅkhepa mattena iva vissajjehi
translated: Question: But how, reverend Sir, has the contemplation of principles been analysed and taught by the Fortunate One, please explain that in brief.

original: Vissajjanā – idha bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati, pañcasu nīvaraṇesu evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā pañcahi pabbehi dhammānupassanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: vissajjanā idha bhikkhave bhikkhu dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati pañcasu nīvaraṇesu evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā pañcahi pabbehi dhamma anupassanā vibhajitvā pakāsitā
translated: The Releasing: here, monks, a monk dwells contemplating (the nature of) things in (various) things, in the five hindrances, and so on, in this way, reverend Sir, there the Fortunate One, after dividing the contemplation of (the nature of) things with five aspects, explained it.

original: Cūḷasīhanādasutta
analyzed: cūḷa sīhanāda sutta
translated: The Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

original: Pucchā – cūḷanasīhanādasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā cūḷanasīhanāda suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: The Question: Now where was the Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar, venerable Sir, spoken by the Fortunate One, for whom was it spoken, and for what reason?

original: Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante parihīnalābhasakkāre nānātitthiye ārabbha bhāsitaṃ,
analyzed: vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante parihīna lābha sakkāre nānā titthiye ārabbha bhāsitam
translated: The Releasing: at Sāvatthī, reverend Sir, for those who had fallen away from gain and honour, for various sectarians it was spoken,

original: nānātitthiyā bhante parihīnalābhasakkārā tesu tesu ṭhānesu parideviṃsu, catasso ca
analyzed: nānā titthiyāḥ bhante parihīna lābha sakkārā tesu tesu ṭhānesu catasso ca
translated: various sectarians, reverend Sir, who had fallen away from gain and honour, lamented in various places, and four assemblies, reverend Sir,

original: bhante parisā bhagavato ekamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ, tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: bhante parisāḥ bhagavato eka mattham ārocesuṃ tasmin bhante vatthusmin bhāsitam
translated: announced the same matter to the Fortunate One, in this matter, reverend Sir, it was spoken.

original: Mahāsīhanādasutta
analyzed: mahāsīhanādasutta
translated: The Greater Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

original: Pucchā – tenāvuso bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena mahāsīhanādasuttaṃ kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā tena āvuso bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena mahāsīhanāda suttam kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitaṃ
translated: The Question: Now where was the Greater Discourse on the Lion’s Roar, venerable Sir, spoken by the Fortunate One, who knew, who saw, the Worthy One, the Perfect Sambuddha, for whom was it spoken, and for what reason?

original: Vissajjanā – vesāliyaṃ bhante sunakkhattaṃ licchaviputtaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ, sanukkhatto
analyzed: vissajjanā vesāliyam bhante sunakkhattam licchavi puttam ārabbha bhāsitam sanukkhatto
translated: The Releasing – in Vesālī, venerable, concerning Sunakkhatta, the son of Likkhitī,

original: bhante licchaviputto acirapakkanto hoti imasmā dhammavinayā, so vesāliyaṃ parisati
analyzed: bhante licchavi putto acira pakkantaḥ hoti imasmai dhamma vinayā saḥ vesāliyam parisati
translated: Sunakkhatta, venerable, the son of Likkhitī, not long after he had gone forth from this Dhamma and Discipline, in Vesālī, in the assembly,

original: evaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati “natthi samaṇassa gotamassa uttarimanussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso,
analyzed: evam vācam bhāsati natthi samaṇassa gotamassa uttari manussa dhammāḥ alam ariya ñāṇa dassana viseso
translated: said this: “There is no superhuman, there is no distinction in knowledge and insight of a higher kind than that of the ascetic Gotama,

original: takkapariyāhataṃ samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ deseti vīmaṃsānucaritaṃ sayaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.
analyzed: takka pariyāhatam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ dhammam deseti vīmaṃsa anucaritam sayam paṭibhānam
translated: the ascetic Gotama teaches a Dhamma hammered out by reasoning, following his own line of inquiry as it occurs to him.

original: Yassa ca khvāssa atthāya dhammo desito, so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāyā”ti,
analyzed: yassa ca khvā assa atthāya dhammo desito so niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkha kkhayāya ati
translated: And for the sake of which the Dhamma is taught, that does not lead to the goal, does not lead to the complete destruction of suffering.”

original: etamatthaṃ bhante āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato ārocesi, tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.

analyzed: pucchā tena āvuso jānatāpe sammāsambuddhena cūḷahatthipadopama suttam kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam  vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante jāṇussoṇim brāhmaṇam ārabbha bhāsitam jāṇussoṇi
translated: Question: With what as the cause, reverend Sir, with what as the origin, with what as the condition, did the Fortunate One speak about the Shorter Discourse on the Elephant’s Footprint?

analyzed: bhante brāhmaṇaḥ bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā yāvatakaḥ ahosi pilotikena paribbājakena
translated: Answer: With the brahmin Jānussoṇi as the cause, reverend Sir, with the brahmin Jānussoṇi as the origin, with the brahmin Jānussoṇi as the condition, the Fortunate One spoke about the Shorter Discourse on the Elephant’s Footprint. The brahmin Jānussoṇi, reverend Sir, approached the Fortunate One, and whatever conversation there was with the wanderer Pilindavaccha

original: saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo, taṃ sabbaṃ bhagavato ārocesi, tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: saddhim kathā sallāpaḥ tam sabbam bhagavataḥ ārocesi tasmim bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: and the conversation that took place, all that he reported to the Fortunate One, in this matter, reverend Sir, it was spoken.”

analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso bhagavā hatthi pada upamam vitthārena paripūretvā desesi

analyzed: vissajjanā na kho brāhmaṇaḥ ettāvatā hatthi pada upamaḥ vitthārena paripūraḥ hoti api
translated: Answer: “The Elephant simile is not fulfilled, Brahmin, by just this much, but,

analyzed: ca brāhmaṇa yathā hatthi pada upamaḥ vitthārena paripūraḥ hoti tam suṇāhi sādhukam manasikarohi

translated: I will speak.” In this way, reverend Sir, the Fortunate One, after fulfilling the Elephant simile, explained it to the Brahmin Jāṇussoṇi.

original: Mahāhatthipadopamasutta

translated: The Great Elephant Simile Discourse

analyzed: pucchā mahāhatthipadopama suttam pana āvuso kattha kam ārabbha kena bhāsitam
translated: Question: But, reverend Sir, where was the Great Elephant Simile Discourse spoken, and for whom, and by whom?

original: Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha āyasmatā sāriputtattherena dhammasenāpatinā bhāsitaṃ.🔽Mahāsāropamasutta
analyzed: vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante sambahule bhikkhū ārabbha āyasmatā sāriputta therena dhamma senāpatinā bhāsitam 🔽mahāsāropamasutta

analyzed: pucchā mahāsāropama suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam

original: Vissajjanā – rājagahe bhante devadattaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ, devadatto bhante saṅghaṃ bhinditvā ruhiruppādakammaṃ katvā acirapakkanto hoti, tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā rājagahe bhante devadattam ārabbha bhāsitam devadattaḥ bhante saṅgham bhinditvā ruhira uppāda kammam katvā acira pakkantaḥ hoti tasmim bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: Answer – “At Rājagaha, friend, it was delivered by the Lord with reference to Devadatta, for soon after Devadatta had gone away, having split the Order, having done the deed of immediate retribution, the Lord was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove at the squirrels’ feeding place.

original: Cūḷasāropamasutta
analyzed: cūḍasāra upama sutta
translated: The Shorter Discourse on the Simile of the Saw

original: Pucchā – cūḷasāropamasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.

translated: Question – “Friend, where was the Shorter Discourse on the Simile of the Saw delivered by the Lord, on what subject, with what occasion?”

original: Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante piṅgalakocchaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ, piṅgalakoccho bhante brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchi, tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante piṅgalakoccham brāhmaṇam ārabbha bhāsitam piṅgalakocchaḥ bhante brāhmaṇaḥ bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchi tasmim bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: Answer – “At Sāvatthī, friend, it was delivered by the Lord with reference to the brahmin Piṅgīyānī, for the brahmin Piṅgīyānī came to the Lord and asked him a question, and the Lord delivered this discourse with reference to that question.

original: Cūḷagosiṅgasutta

analyzed: pucchā cūḷagosiṅga suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kena saddhim bhāsitam
translated: Question – “Friend, with whom was the Shorter Discourse on Gosiṅga delivered by the Lord?”

original: Vissajjanā – nābhike bhante gosiṅgasālavanadāye āyasmatā anuruddhattherena saddhiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā nābhike bhante gosiṅgasālavana dāye āyasmatā anuruddha ttherena saddhim bhāsitam
translated: The answer is: at the Gosiṅga Sal Wood, venerable sir, by the venerable Anuruddha the Elder in conversation with.

translated: Question: Where, friend, was the Great Advice Sutta delivered by the Blessed One, and with whom?

original: Vissajjanā – gosiṅgasālavanadāye bhante āyasmatā ca sāriputtattherena dhammasenāpatinā āyasmatā ca mahāmoggallānattherena saddhiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vissajjanā gosiṅga sāla vana dāye bhante āyasmatā ca sāriputta therena dhamma senāpatinā āyasmatā ca mahāmoggallāna ttherena saddhim bhāsitam
translated: Answer: At the Gosiṅga Sal Wood, venerable sir, by the venerable Sāriputta the Elder, the general of the Dhamma, and by the venerable Mahā Moggallāna the Elder.

translated: Question: By the Blessed One, friend, where was the Great Advice to Rāhula Sutta delivered, and with reference to whom?

analyzed: pucchā cūḷagopālaka suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha bhāsitam

analyzed: pucchā tena āvuso jānatāpe sammāsambuddhena cūḷasaccaka suttam kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: Question “By whom was the Cūḷasaccaka Sutta spoken? To whom was it spoken? On what subject was it spoken?”

original: Vissajjanā – vesāliyaṃ bhante saccakaṃ nigaṇṭhaputtaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ, saccako nigaṇṭhaputto🔽mahatiyā licchaviparisāya saddhiṃ yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ🔽etadavoca “kathaṃ pana bhavaṃ gotamo sāvake vineti, kathaṃ bhāgā ca pana bhoto gotamassa🔽sāvakesu anusāsanī bahulā pavattatī”ti, atha bhante bhagavatā aniccavāde ca anattavāde
analyzed: vissajjanā vesāliyam bhante saccakam nigaṇṭha puttam ārabbha bhāsitam saccakaḥ nigaṇṭha putto  mahatiyā licchavi parisāya saddhim yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam  etat avoca katham pana bhavam gotamaḥ sāvake vineti katham bhāgā ca pana bhoto gotamassa  sāvakesu anusāsanī bahulā pavattati iti atha bhante bhagavatā anicca vāde ca anatta vāde
translated: Answer “At Vesālī, friend, it was spoken by the Lord to Saccaka the son of Nigaṇṭha.

translated: Question: – When Saccaka the son of Nigan.tha had thus shown the simile of the great earth and had set forth his own doctrine, how did the Blessed One re-establish that doctrine and then question, cross-question, and converse with him?

translated: Reply: – “But, Aggivessana, do you speak thus: ‘Material form is my self, feeling is my self,

translated: perception is my self, mental formations are my self, consciousness is my self’?” – “Yes, lord.”

analyzed: evamādinā bhante bhagavā saccakam nigaṇṭha puttam samanuyuñji samanugāhi samanubhāsi
translated: Thus, venerable sir, the Blessed One re-established Saccaka the son of Nigan.tha in his own doctrine.🔽And after re-establishing him, venerable sir, the Blessed One questioned, cross-questioned, and conversed with him.

original: Pucchā – evaṃ kho āvuso saccake nigaṇṭhaputte tuṇhībhūte adhomukhe pajjhāyante appaṭibhāne nisinne dummukho nāma licchaviputto bhagavantaṃ kiṃ vacanaṃ avoca.🔽Vissajjanā – evaṃ bhante saccake nigaṇṭhaputte tuṇhībhūte maṅkubhūte pattakkhandhe
analyzed: pucchā evam kho āvuso saccake nigaṇṭha putte tuṇhībhūte adhomukhe pajjhāyante appaṭibhāne nisinne dummukhaḥ nāma licchavi puttaḥ bhagavantam kim vacanam avoca  vissajjanā evam bhante saccake nigaṇṭha putte tuṇhībhūte maṅku bhūte patta kkhandhe
translated: Question – When Saccaka the son of Nigan.tha had become silent, with his face fallen, and was sitting there abashed and tongue-tied, what did Dummukha the son of the Licchavis say to the Lord?

original: adhomukhe pajjhāyante appaṭibhāne dummukho licchaviputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca “upamā🔽maṃ bhagavā paṭibhātī”ti.
analyzed: adhomukhe pajjhāyante appaṭibhāne dummukhaḥ licchavi puttaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca upamā  mam bhagavā paṭibhāti iti
translated: Answer – When Saccaka the son of Nigan.tha had become silent, abashed, with shoulders drooping and head down, sitting there abashed and tongue-tied, Dummukha the son of the Licchavis said this to the Lord: “It would be good, Lord, if the Lord would give an illustration.”

original: Pucchā – atha kho āvuso saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavantaṃ kīdisaṃ pañhaṃ pucchi, kathañca taṃ bhagavā byākāsi.
analyzed: pucchā atha kho āvuso saccakaḥ nigaṇṭha puttaḥ bhagavantam kīdisam pañham pucchi kathañca tam bhagavā byākāsi
translated: Question – Then, venerable Sir, what kind of question did Saccaka the son of Nigan.tha ask, and how did the Lord answer it?

analyzed: vissajjanā atha kho bhante saccakaḥ nigaṇṭha puttaḥ dummukham licchavim apasādetvā
translated: Answer – Then, venerable Sir, after Dummukha the son of the Licchavis had reproved Saccaka the son of Nigan.tha,

analyzed: bhagavantam sekhan ca a sekhan ca pañham pucchi bhagavā ca bhante idha aggivessana
translated: he asked the Lord a question about the one who is in training and the one who is beyond training, and the Lord said this, venerable Sir: “Here, Aggivessana,

original: mama sāvako yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ🔽vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā” evamādinā sekhañca asekhañca
analyzed: mama sāvakaḥ yam kiñci rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikam  vā sukhumam vā hīnam vā paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā evamādinā sekhan ca a sekhan ca
translated: “Whatever material form there is, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near,

analyzed: puggalam vibhajitvā  buddhaḥ saḥ bhagavā bodhāya dhammam deseti
translated: having thus divided the person in training and the person beyond training, he explained.🔽The Enlightened One, the Blessed One, teaches the Dhamma for the sake of enlightenment.

original: Danto so bhagavā damathāya dhammaṃ deseti.🔽Santo so bhagavā samathāya dhammaṃ deseti.
analyzed: dantaḥ so bhagavā damathāya dhammam deseti  santaḥ so bhagavā samathāya dhammaṃ deseti
translated: The One with Mastery, the Blessed One, teaches the Dhamma for the sake of mastery.🔽The Peaceful One, the Blessed One, teaches the Dhamma for the sake of peace.

original: Tiṇṇo so bhagavā taraṇāya dhammaṃ deseti.
analyzed: tiṇṇaḥ saḥ bhagavā taraṇāya dhammam deseti

original: Parinibbuto so bhagavā parinibbānāya dhammaṃ deseti.
analyzed: parinibbutaḥ saḥ bhagavā parinibbānāya dhammam deseti
translated: The One who is Fully Extinguished, the Blessed One, teaches the Dhamma for the sake of full extinguishment.

original: Mahāsaccakasutta
analyzed: mahāsaccaka sutta
translated: The Great Discourse to Saccaka

original: Pucchā – mahāsaccakasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.🔽Vissajjanā – vesāliyaṃ bhante saccakaṃyeva nigaṇṭhaputtaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ. Saccako
analyzed: pucchā mahāsaccaka suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam  vissajjanā vesāliyam bhante saccakam yeva nigaṇṭha puttam ārabbha bhāsitam
translated: Question: Where was the Great Discourse to Saccaka spoken? By whom was it spoken? To whom was it spoken? For what reason was it spoken?

original: bhante nigaṇṭhaputto aparadivase bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato sāvake āsajja
analyzed: bhante nigaṇṭha puttaḥ apara divase bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā bhagavataḥ sāvake āsajja
translated: Answer: In Vesālī, venerable Sir, it was spoken by the Fortunate One, referring to Saccaka, the son of Nigaṇṭha. Saccaka, venerable Sir, the son of Nigaṇṭha, having approached the Fortunate One on another day, having abused the Fortunate One’s disciples,

original: bhāvanādvayapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ vācaṃ bhāsati, tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvanā dvaya paṭisaṃyuttam vācam bhāsati tasmim bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: he spoke words connected with the two cultivations, in that case, reverend Sir, he spoke.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso bhagavā saccakaṃ nigaṇṭhaputtaṃ paṭipucchitvā bhāvanādvayaṃ vibhajja kathesi.
analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso bhagavā saccakam nigaṇṭha puttam paṭipucchitvā bhāvanā dvayam vibhajja kathesi
translated: Question: But, friend, how did the Fortunate One, after questioning Saccaka the son of Nigaṇṭha, explain the two cultivations after analysing them?

original: Vissajjanā – atha kho bhante bhagavā “kinti pana te aggivessana kāyabhāvanā sutā”ti
analyzed: vissajjanā atha kho bhante bhagavā kinti pana te aggivessana kāya bhāvanā sutā ati
translated: Answer: Then, reverend Sir, the Fortunate One (said): “But what kind of cultivation of the body have you heard about, Aggivessana?”

analyzed: evamādinā saccakam nigaṇṭha puttam paṭipucchitvā katham ca aggivessana abhāvita kāyaḥ
translated: and so on, after questioning Saccaka the son of Nigaṇṭha, and (said): “And how, Aggivessana, is there a body that is uncultivated,

original: ca hoti abhāvitacitto ca evamādinā bhāvanādvayaṃ vibhajitvā byākāsi.

translated: And, venerable sir, the householder Upāli, having thus obtained permission from the Blessed One, expounded his own teacher’s doctrine thus:🔽‘Venerable sir, my teacher, the venerable Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta, is thus described by his pupils: “This Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta is a perfected one, supremely enlightened, one who has accomplished the task, a supreme teacher of gods and men, a Buddha, an unsurpassed guide for those people who need taming.” This is the doctrine of my teacher, venerable sir, the venerable Nāṭaputta: “As long as a person’s bodily action is impure, his verbal action is impure, and his mental action is impure, and he does not have the knowledge as it really is of the origination of the body, of the origination of speech, of the origination of the mind, of the cessation of the body, of the cessation of speech, of the cessation of the mind, and of the path leading to the cessation of the mind, then he is called a person with an impure body, an impure mind, and an impure life, and he is also called a person who has not entered upon the way of the higher austerity.

original: nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa vādaṃ pakāsesi, vādaṃ vaṇṇesi. Tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.

original: Pucchā – atha kho āvuso bhagavā upāliṃ gahapatiṃ tasmiṃ vāde kathaṃ samanuyuñjī samanugāhī samanubhāsī, kathañcassa upāyaṃ dassetvā yathābhūtaṃ atthaṃ ñāpesi.

original: sabbadassāvī aparisesaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paṭijānāti, carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa
analyzed: sabba dassāvī aparisesam ñāṇa dassanam paṭijānāti carataḥ ca me tiṭṭhataḥ ca suttassa
translated: to have all-embracing knowledge and vision, to be able to teach the Dhamma after directly knowing and experiencing it himself. And he claims that while he is walking, standing, sleeping, and waking,

original: ca jāgarassa ca satataṃ samitaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhita”nti. Ye te bhante evamāhaṃsu🔽“samaṇo gotamo sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paṭijānāti, carato ca🔽me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṃ samitaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ paccupaṭṭhita”nti.
analyzed: ca jāgarassa ca satatam samitam ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitanti ye te bhante evam āhaṃsu  samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ sabbaññū sabba dassāvī aparisesam ñāṇa dassanam paṭijānāti carataḥ ca  me tiṭṭhataḥ ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satatam samitam ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitanti
translated: knowledge and vision are constantly and continuously present to him.’ Those who say this, venerable sir,

original: Kacci te bhante bhagavato vuttavādino, na ca bhagavantaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkhanti,
analyzed: kacci te bhante bhagavataḥ vutta vādinaḥ na ca bhagavantam abhūtena abbhācikkhanti
translated: do they say what has been said by the Blessed One, and not misrepresent him with what is contrary to fact?🔽Do they explain in accordance with the Dhamma in such a way that nothing which provides a ground for censure can be legitimately deduced from their assertion?”

original: dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākaronti, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ
analyzed: dhammassa ca anudhammam byākaronti na ca koci sahadhammikaḥ vādānuvādaḥ gārayham ṭhānam
translated: and they explain in accordance with the Teaching, and no one can reasonably criticize their explanation of the Teaching as being incorrect,

original: āgacchatī”ti. Tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: āgacchati iti tasmim bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: and they explain in accordance with the Dhamma, and no one can reasonably reprove them for misrepresenting the Dhamma.” This is the source.

original: Aggivacchasutta
analyzed: aggivacchasutta
translated: The Discourse to Aggivessana🔽“And where, friend, was the Discourse to Aggivessana spoken by the Fortunate One?

original: Pucchā – aggivacchasuttaṃ panāvuso kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā aggivaccha suttam pana āvuso kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: To whom was it spoken?🔽For what reason was it spoken?”

original: Vissajjanā – sāvatthiyaṃ bhante vacchagottaṃ paribbājakaṃ bhāsitaṃ. Vacchagotto bhante
analyzed: vissajjanā sāvatthiyam bhante vacchagottam paribbājakam bhāsitam vacchagottaḥ bhante
translated: “At Sāvatthī, friend, the wanderer Vacchagotta was spoken to.

original: paribbājako bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā “kiṃ nu kho bho gotama ‘sassato loko idameva
analyzed: paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā kim nu kho bho gotama sassataḥ lokaḥ idam eva
translated: The wanderer Vacchagotta, friend, after approaching the Fortunate One, asked this question: ‘Now then, Master Gotama, does the world exist like this,🔽and this alone is the truth, and (all) else is foolish?’ and so on.

original: saccaṃ moghamañña’nti evaṃdiṭṭhi bhavaṃ gotamo”ti evamādikaṃ pañhaṃ apucchi. Tasmiṃ🔽bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: saccam mogham aññanti evaṃdiṭṭhi bhavam gotama iti evamādikam pañham apucchi tasmin  bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: This is the source.”

original: Mahāvacchasutta
analyzed: mahāvaccha sutta
translated: The Long Discourse to Vacchagotta🔽“And where, friend, was the Long Discourse to Vacchagotta spoken by the Fortunate One?

original: Pucchā – mahāvacchasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā mahāvaccha suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: To whom was it spoken?🔽For what reason was it spoken?”

original: Vissajjanā – rājagahe bhante vacchagottaṃyeva paribbājakaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ. Vacchagotto
analyzed: vissajjanā rājagahe bhante vacchagottam yā iva paribbājakam ārabbha bhāsitam
translated: The Releasing: at Rājagaha, venerable, concerning the wanderer Vacchagotta. The wanderer

original: bhante paribbājako bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca “dīgharattāhaṃ bhotā gotamena🔽sahakathī, sādhu me bhavaṃ gotamo saṃkhittena kusalākusalaṃ desetū”ti. Tasmiṃ bhante
analyzed: bhante paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā etat avoca dīgharattā aham bhotā gotamena  saha kathī sādhu me bhavam gotamaḥ saṃkhittena kusala akusalam desetu uti tasmin bhante
translated: Vacchagotta, venerable, approached the Fortunate One and said this: “For a long time, dear Gotama,

original: vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: vatthusmin bhāsitam
translated: we have been able to talk together, it would be good if the dear Gotama would teach me the Dhamma in brief.” In that matter, venerable, it was said.

original: Pucchā – evaṃ vutte kho āvuso vacchagotto paribbājako imasmiṃ dhammavinaye pasanno hutvā kīdisaṃ pasannākāraṃ akāsi, kathañcassa dhammābhisamayo ahosi.
analyzed: pucchā evam vutte kho āvuso vaccha gottaḥ paribbājakaḥ imasmin dhamma vinaye pasannaḥ hutvā kīdisam pasanna ākāram akāsi katham ca assa dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi
translated: The Questions: When this was said, venerable friends, the wanderer Vacchagotta, having confidence in this Dhamma and Discipline, what kind of sign of confidence did he make, and how did he attain the Dharma?

original: Vissajjanā – evaṃ vutte bhante vacchagotto paribbājako “sace hi bho gotama imaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā evam vutte bhante vaccha gottaḥ paribbājako sace hi bho gotamaḥ imam dhammaṃ
translated: The Releasing: When this was said, venerable, the wanderer Vacchagotta: “If, dear Gotama,

original: bhavaṃyeva gotamo ārādhako abhavissa, no ca kho bhikkhū ārādhakā abhavissaṃsu, evamidaṃ
analyzed: bhavaṃyā iva gotamaḥ ārādhakaḥ abhavissa no ca kho bhikkhū ārādhakāḥ abhavissaṃsu evam idam
translated: only the dear Gotama would have perfected this Dhamma, and the monks would not have perfected it, then

original: brahmacariyaṃ aparipūraṃ abhavissa tenaṅgenā”ti evamādinā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye pasanno
analyzed: brahmacariyam a paripūram abhavissa tena aṅgena ati evamādinā imasmin dhamma vinaye pasannaḥ
translated: this spiritual life would be incomplete in that respect.” In this way, venerable, having confidence in this Dhamma and Discipline,

original: pasannākāramakāsi. Yāva arahattañcassa dhammābhisamayo ahosi.
analyzed: pasanna ākāram akāsi yāva arahattañca assa dhamma abhisamayaḥ ahosi
translated: and he attained Arahatship together with the Supernatural Faculties.

original: Dīghanakhasutta
analyzed: dīgha nakha sutta
translated: The Discourse with Dīghanakha

original: Pucchā – dīghanakhasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā dīghanakha suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: Question: Where was the Dīghanakha Discourse spoken by the Blessed One, to whom was it spoken, and on what subject?

original: Vissajjanā – rājagahe bhante dīghanakhaṃ paribbājakaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ. Dīghanakho
analyzed: vissajjanā rājagahe bhante dīghanakham paribbājakam ārabbha bhāsitam dīghanakhaḥ
translated: Reply: At Rājagaha, venerable Sir, it was spoken to the wanderer Dīghanakha, and on the subject of the wanderer Dīghanakha

original: bhante paribbājako bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca “ahañhi bho gotama evaṃvādī
analyzed: bhante paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā etat avoca aham hi bho gotamaḥ evaṃvādī
translated: venerable Sir, having approached the Blessed One, spoke thus: “I, Reverend Gotama, am one who speaks thus,

original: evaṃdiṭṭhi sabbaṃ me nakkhamatī”ti. Tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: evaṃdiṭṭhi sabbam me na khamati iti tasmim bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: I am one who holds this view: all is acceptable to me.” On this subject, venerable Sir, it was spoken.

original: Pucchā – imasmiṃ ca panāvuso veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne kesaṃ puggalānaṃ visesādhigamo ahosi.
analyzed: pucchā imasmim ca pana āvuso veyyākaraṇasmim bhaññamāne kesam puggalānam visesa adhigamaḥ ahosi
translated: Question: And in what persons, friend, did the attainment of distinction arise in this explanation?

original: Vissajjanā – imasmiñca pana bhante veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne āyasmato sāriputtassa
analyzed: vissajjanā imasmin ca pana bhante veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa
translated: Reply: And in this explanation, venerable Sir, the venerable Sāriputta’s🔽mind was freed from the pollutants without attachment, and Dīghanakha the wanderer’s mind

original: anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimucci, dīghanakhassa pana paribbājakassa tasmiṃyeva āsane
analyzed: an upādāya āsavehi cittam vimucci dīghanakhassa pana paribbājakassa tasmiṃ yeva āsane
translated: was freed from the pollutants without attachment, sitting right there.

original: virajaṃ vītamalaṃ dhammacakkhuṃ udapādi yaṃkiñci samudayadhammaṃ, sabbaṃ taṃ nirodhadhamma”nti.
analyzed: virajam vīta malam dhamma cakkhum udapādi yaṃ kiñci samudaya dhammam sabbam tat nirodha dhamman ti
translated: the dust-free, stainless Dhamma-eye arose: ‘Whatever is of the nature to arise, all that is of the nature to stop.’ ”

original: Māgaṇḍiyasutta
analyzed: māgaṇḍiyasutta
translated: The Discussion with Magandiya

original: Pucchā – māgaṇḍiyasuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.🔽Vissajjanā – kurūsu bhante kammāsadhamme nāma kurūnaṃ nigame bhāradvāja gottassa
analyzed: pucchā māgaṇḍiya suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam  vissajjanā kurūsu bhante kammāsadhamme nāma kurūnam nigame bhāradvāja gottassa
translated: Question: Where was the Discussion with Magandiya given, reverend Sir, to whom and on what subject?

original: brāhmaṇassa agyāgāre tiṇasanthārake māgaṇḍiyaṃ paribbājakaṃ ārabbha bhāsitaṃ. Māgaṇḍiyo
analyzed: brāhmaṇassa agyāgāre tiṇa santhārake māgaṇḍiyam paribbājakam ārabbha bhāsitam māgaṇḍiyaḥ
translated: Reply: In the Kuru country, reverend Sir, in the town of Kammasadhamma of the Kurus, in the fire-chamber of a brahmin of the Bharadvaja clan, on a bed of grass, reverend Sir, the Discussion with Magandiya was given to the wanderer Magandiya.

original: bhante paribbājako bhagavantaṃ “bhūnahu samaṇo gotamo”ti vadesi, tasmiṃ bhante vaṭṭhusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: bhante paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam bhūnahu samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ iti vadesi tasmim bhante vaṭṭhusmim bhāsitam
translated: Magandiya, reverend Sir, said to the Fortunate One: “You are a magician, ascetic.” On that subject, reverend Sir, the Discussion was given.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso bhagavā tattha māgaṇḍiyassa paribbājakassa samanuyuñjitvā samanuyuñjitvā dhammaṃ desesi.
analyzed: pucchā kathañca āvuso bhagavā tattha māgaṇḍiyassa paribbājakassa samanuyuñjitvā samanuyuñjitvā dhammaṃ desesi
translated: Question: But how, reverend Sir, did the Fortunate One, after pressing and pressing the wanderer Magandiya, give a Dhamma talk?

original: Vissajjanā – “cakkhuṃ kho māgaṇḍiya rūpārataṃ rūpasammuditaṃ, taṃ tathāgatassa dantaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā cakkhum kho māgaṇḍiya rūpa āratam rūpa sammuditam tam tathāgatassa dantam
translated: Reply: “The eye, Magandiya, is delightful and pleasurable, and there the Realised One’s is restrained,

original: guttaṃ rakkhitaṃ saṃvutaṃ, tassa ca saṃvarāya dhammaṃ desetī”ti evamādinā bhante
analyzed: guttam rakkhitam saṃvutam tassa ca saṃvarāya dhammaṃ deseti iti evamādinā bhante
translated: guarded, protected, restrained, and he teaches the Dhamma for the restraint of those (who are not so restrained).’

original: tattha bhagavā māgaṇḍiyassa paribbājakassa samanuyuñjitvā samanuyuñjitvā dhammaṃ desesi.🔽Pucchā – evaṃ kho āvuso māgaṇḍiyena paribbājakena “nakiñci bho gotamā”ti yathābhūtaṃ paṭissute kathaṃ bhagavā attanopi na kiñci kenacipi vattabbataṃ pakāsesi.
analyzed: tattha bhagavā māgaṇḍiyassa paribbājakassa samanuyuñjitvā samanuyuñjitvā dhammaṃ desesi  pucchā evam kho āvuso māgaṇḍiyena paribbājakena na kiñci bho gotama ati yathābhūtam paṭissute katham bhagavā attanaḥ api na kiñci kenacipi vattabbatam pakāsesi
translated: There the Fortunate One, after pressing Māgaṇḍiya the wanderer in the matter of this, taught the Dhamma.🔽Question: But when Māgaṇḍiya the wanderer said: “There is nothing, reverend Gotama,” and the Fortunate One replied: “So it is, Māgaṇḍiya, so it is, Māgaṇḍiya,” how did the Fortunate One make it known that he had nothing to be said by anyone?

original: Vissajjanā – evaṃ kho bhante māgaṇḍiyena paribbājakena nakiñci bhogotamāti yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā evam kho bhante māgaṇḍiyena paribbājakena na kiñci bhogotama ati yathābhūtam
translated: Answer: But when Māgaṇḍiya the wanderer said: “There is nothing, reverend Gotama,” and the Fortunate One replied: “So it is, Māgaṇḍiya, so it is, Māgaṇḍiya,”

original: paṭissute “ahaṃ kho pana māgaṇḍiya pubbe agāriyabhūto samāno pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito🔽samaṅgībhūto paricāresiṃ cakkhuviññeyyahi rūpehi iṭṭhehi manāpehi piyarūpehi kāmūpasaṃhitehi
analyzed: paṭissute aham kho pana māgaṇḍiya pubbe agāriya bhūtaḥ samāno pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitaḥ  samaṅgībhūtaḥ paricāresim cakkhu viññeyyahi rūpehi iṭṭhehi manāpehi piya rūpehi kāma upasaṃhitehi
translated: the Fortunate One made it known that he had nothing to be said by anyone with: “But, Māgaṇḍiya, formerly, when I was a householder, I was endowed with, and possessed of, the five strands of sense pleasure,

original: rajanīyehī”ti evamādinā bhagavā attanopi na kiñci kenacipi vattabbataṃ pakāsesi.
analyzed: rajanīyehi iti evamādinā bhagavā attanaḥ api na kiñci kenacipi vattabbatam pakāsesi
translated: and I used them, not being enslaved to them, not being a slave to them, not being dependent on them, not being a slave infatuated by them.”

original: Pucchā – imasmiṃ sutte pariyosānapucchaṃ pucchissāmi imañca panāvuso dhammadesanaṃ sutvā māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako imasmiṃ dhammavinaye pasanno hutvā kīdisaṃ pasannākāramakāsi.🔽Vissajjanā – imaṃ ca pana bhante dhammadesanaṃ sutvā māgaṇḍiyo paribbājako ‘abhikkantaṃ
analyzed: pucchā imasmim sutte pariyosāna puccham pucchissāmi imam ca pana āvuso dhamma desanam sutvā māgaṇḍiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ imasmim dhamma vinaye pasannaḥ hutvā kīdisam pasanna ākāram akāsi  vissajjanā imam ca pana bhante dhamma desanam sutvā māgaṇḍiyaḥ paribbājakaḥ abhikkantam
translated: Question – In this sutta I shall ask a question about the conclusion. And after hearing this teaching of the Dhamma, the wanderer Magandiya, having become confident in this Dhamma and Discipline, what kind of sign of confidence did he make?

original: bho gotama abhikkantaṃ bho gotamā”ti evamādinā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye pasanno pasannākāramakāsi.
analyzed: bho gotama abhikkantam bho gotama ati evamādinā imasmin dhamma vinaye pasannaḥ pasanna ākāram akāsi
translated: Answer – And after hearing this teaching of the Dhamma, the wanderer Magandiya, saying: “Excellent, reverend Gotama, excellent, reverend Gotama,” made this kind of sign of confidence in this Dhamma and Discipline.

original: Sandakasutta
analyzed: sandaka sutta
translated: The Discourse with Sandaka

original: Pucchā – sandakasuttaṃ panāvuso kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ kena bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā sandaka suttam pana āvuso kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim kena bhāsitam
translated: Question – But, friend, with regard to the Discourse with Sandaka, where was it spoken, about whom was it spoken, on account of what was it spoken, by whom was it spoken?

original: Vissajjanā – kosambiyaṃ bhante sandakaṃ paribbājakaṃ ārabbha āyasmatā ānandattherena
analyzed: vissajjanā kosambiyam bhante sandakam paribbājakam ārabbha āyasmatā ānanda therena
translated: Answer – At Kosambī, reverend Sir, about the wanderer Sandaka, by the venerable Elder Ānanda,

original: dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena bhāsitaṃ. Sandako bhante paribbājako āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca
analyzed: dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena bhāsitam sandakaḥ bhante paribbājakaḥ āyasmantam ānandam etat avoca
translated: the superintendent of the Dhamma, it was spoken. The wanderer Sandaka, reverend Sir, said this to the venerable Ānanda:

original: “sādhuvata bhavantaṃyeva ānandaṃ paṭibhātu sake ācariya ke dhammikathā”ti, tasmiṃ
analyzed: sādhuvata bhavantam yā iva ānandam paṭibhātu sake ācariya ke dhammi kathā ati tasmin
translated: “Well then, let the venerable Ānanda himself remember the Dhamma discussion in his own teacher’s presence.”

original: bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: bhante vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: This is the context, venerable sir.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha cattāro abrahmacariyavāsā āyasmatā ānandattherena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena vicāretvā pakāsitā.🔽Vissajjanā – idha sandaka ekacco satthā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi natthi dinnaṃ, natthi🔽yiṭṭhaṃ, natthi hutaṃ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃvipāko, natthi ayaṃloko,
analyzed: pucchā kathañca āvuso tattha cattāro abrahmacariya vāsāḥ āyasmatā ānanda therena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena vicāretvā pakāsitā  vissajjanā idha sandake ekaccaḥ satthā evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi natthi dinnam natthi  yiṭṭham natthi hutam natthi su kata dukkaṭānam kammānam phalaṃ vipākaḥ natthi ayaṃ loko
translated: Question: But how, friend, were the four kinds of living in a hole of an unvirtuous life explained by the venerable Ānanda, the Elder who was the Dhamma Treasurer?

original: natthi paroloko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikāti
analyzed: natthi parolokaḥ natthi mātā natthi pitā natthi sattā opapātikā ati
translated: Answer: Here, Sandaka, a certain teacher is of this view, this opinion: “There is nothing given, nothing offered, nothing sacrificed. There is no fruit or result of good or bad deeds. There is no this world or the next world. There is no mother or father. There are no spontaneously reborn beings. There are no contemplatives or brahmans in the world who have realised for themselves by direct knowledge and declare this world and the next world.

original: Evamādinā bhante tattha āyasmatā ānandattherena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena cattāro abrahmacariyavāsā vicāretvā pakāsitā.
analyzed: evamādinā bhante tattha āyasmatā ānanda therena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena cattāraḥ abrahmacariya vāsāḥ vicāretvā pakāsitā
translated: In this way, venerable sir, the four kinds of living in a hole of an unvirtuous life were explained by the venerable Ānanda, the Elder who was the Dhamma Treasurer.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha cattāri anassāsikāni brahmacariyāni āyasmatā ānandattherena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena vicāretvā pakāsitāni.
analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso tattha cattāri anassāsikāni brahmacariyāni āyasmatā ānanda therena dhammabhaṇḍāgārikena vicāretvā pakāsitāni
translated: Question: But, reverend Sir, how did the venerable Ānanda, the Lord of the Dhamma, having investigated, reveal the four fruitless forms of life there?

original: Vissajjanā – idha sandaka ekacco satthā sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ
analyzed: vissajjanā idha sandakaḥ ekaccaḥ satthā sabbaññū sabba dassāvī aparisesam ñāṇa dassanam
translated: Answer: Here, Sandaka, a certain teacher claims to be omniscient and all-seeing, and to have complete knowledge and vision thus:

original: paṭijānāti “carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṃ samitaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ
analyzed: paṭijānāti carataḥ ca me tiṭṭhataḥ ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satatam samitam ñāṇa dassanam

translated: One who should be given a seat is not given a seat, one who should not be given a seat is given a seat, one who should be given water is not given water, one who should not be given water is given water, one who should be given a resting place is not given a resting place, one who should be given a lamp is not given a lamp, one who should be given a dwelling is not given a dwelling, one who should be given medicine is not given medicine, one who should be given a requisite is not given a requisite.

original: māneti, pūjetabbaṃ na pūjetīti evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā sattānaṃ uccākulīna
analyzed: māneti pūjetabbam na pūjā iti iti evamādinā bhante tattha bhagavatā sattānam ucca ākulīna
translated: Herein, Blessed One, the Blessed One has analysed and explained the deeds that lead to rebirth in a high family and

original: nīcakulīnasaṃvattanakakammāni vibhajitvā pakāsitāni.
analyzed: nīca kulīna saṃvattanaka kammāni vibhajitvā pakāsitāni
translated: to rebirth in a low family.

original: Pucchā – kathañcāvuso tattha bhagavatā sattānaṃ mahāpaññaduppaññasaṃvattanakakammāni vibhajitvā pakāsitāni.
analyzed: pucchā katham ca āvuso tattha bhagavatā sattānam mahāpañña duppañña saṃvattanaka kammāni vibhajitvā pakāsitāni
translated: Question: But how, friend, has the Blessed One analysed and explained the deeds that lead to great wisdom and to little wisdom?

original: Vissajjanā – idha māṇava ekacco itthī vā puriso vā samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: vissajjanā idha māṇava ekaccaḥ itthī vā purisaḥ vā samaṇam vā brāhmaṇam vā upasaṅkamitvā
translated: Answer: Here, young man, a woman or a man, having approached a recluse or a brahmin,

original: na paripucchitā hoti “kiṃ bhante kusalaṃ, kiṃ akusalaṃ. Kiṃ sāvajjaṃ, kiṃ anavajjaṃ.
analyzed: na paripucchitā hoti kim bhante kusalam kim akusalam kim sāvajjam kim anavajjam
translated: does not ask: ‘What, venerable sir, is wholesome? What is unwholesome? What is blamable? What is blameless?

original: Kiṃ sevitabbaṃ, kiṃ na sevitabbaṃ. Kiṃ me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya
analyzed: kim sevitabbam kim na sevitabbam kim me karīyamānam dīgharattam ahitāya dukkhāya
translated: What should be cultivated? What should not be cultivated? What kind of action will lead to my harm and suffering for a long time?

original: hoti, kiṃ vā pana me karīyamānaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya hotī”ti evamādinā bhante
analyzed: hoti kim vā pana me karīyamānam dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya hoti iti evamādinā bhante
translated: Or what kind of action will lead to my welfare and happiness for a long time?’ and so on.

original: tattha bhagavatā sattānaṃ mahāpaññaduppaññasaṃvattanakakammāni vibhajitvā pakāsitāni.
analyzed: tattha bhagavatā sattānam mahāpañña duppañña saṃvattanaka kammāni vibhajitvā pakāsitāni
translated: Herein, Blessed One, the Blessed One has analysed and explained the deeds that lead to great wisdom and to little wisdom.

original: Indriyabhāvanāsu
analyzed: indriya bhāvanāsu
translated: In the development of the faculties

original: Pucchā – indriyabhāvanāsuttaṃ panāvuso bhagavatā kattha kaṃ ārabbha kismiṃ vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: pucchā indriya bhāvanā suttam pana āvuso bhagavatā kattha kam ārabbha kismim vatthusmim bhāsitam
translated: Question — “Now, where, to whom, and on what subject was the Discourse on the Development of the Faculties delivered by the Blessed One?”

original: Vissajjanā – gajaṅgalāyaṃ bhante uttaraṃ nāma māṇavaṃ pārāsiviyantevāsiṃ ārabbha
analyzed: vissajjanā gajaṅgalāyam bhante uttaram nāma māṇavam pārāsiviya antevāsim ārabbha
translated: Reply — “At Gajaṅgalā, venerable sir, to the youth Uttara, the pupil of the brāhmaṇa Pārāśariya,

original: bhāsitaṃ, uttaro bhante māṇavo pārāsiviyantevāsī bhagavatā puṭṭho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca🔽“idha bho gotama cakkhunā rūpaṃ na passati, sotena saddaṃ na suṇāti. Evaṃ kho bho
analyzed: bhāsitam uttaraḥ bhante māṇavaḥ pārāsiviya antevāsī bhagavatā puṭṭhaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca  idha bho gotama cakkhunā rūpam na passati sotena saddam na suṇāti evam kho bho
translated: and on the subject of the development of the faculties. The youth Uttara, the pupil of the brāhmaṇa Pārāśariya, was asked by the Blessed One and replied:

original: gotama deseti pārāsiviyo brāhmaṇo sāvakānaṃ indriyabhāvana”nti. Tasmiṃ bhante vatthusmiṃ bhāsitaṃ.
analyzed: gotama deseti pārāsiviyaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ sāvakānam tasmin bhante vatthusmin bhāsitam
translated: ‘Here, Master Gotama, one does not see visible forms with the eye, one does not hear sounds with the ear. Thus, Master Gotama, the brāhmaṇa Pārāśariya teaches his disciples the development of the faculties.’ On this subject, venerable sir, the Blessed One spoke.”
